lines.text: [Smith and Schaffer are observing the Castle of Eagles fortress, and a nearby military base]
If I'm not mistaken, that's an army barracks over there.
No mistake, Lieutenant. This the headquarters of the Wehrmacht Alpenkorps.
Oh, swell. Do you have any other surprises I should know about?
I thought you knew, Lieutenant. Why do you think we were chosen for his mission as if not to make social contact?
You mean we're gonna go down there? Mingle with the German Army?
Of course. Why do you think we're not dressed as German sailors?
We'll be recognized as strangers.
Training troops come and go all the time. What are six new faces among 600 new faces?
Look, Major, this is primarily a British operation. I'm an American. I don't even know why the hell I'm here.
Lieutenant, you're here because you're an American.
Lieutenant, in the next 15 minutes we have to create enough confusion to get out of here alive.
Major, right now you got me about as confused as I ever hope to be.

[into a phone]
Major Wilner speaking. Ja, Colonel.

[into a phone]
Can you describe him?

[into the phone]
That will not be necessary. Ask him to show you his right forearm.
Certainly.

[as Smith raises his sleve]
There are two parallel scars, about three centimeters apart.

[into the phone]
The scars are there.

[into the phone]
Ask how he get them.

[to Smith]
How did you get those?
I was born with them.

[into the phone]
He says he was born with them.

[into the phone]
That is right. Tell him he's a traitor.
Tell him he's a renegade.
That is Schmidt. No question about it.

[referring to what Smith called him earlier to maintain his cover]
"Second rate punk," huh?
All I could think of on the spur of the moment.
Thanks, that makes it even worse.

[smiles]
Sorry.

[to Mary]
Strange... I seem to remember... that the cathedral was on the *other* side of the square.
[repeated line]
Broadsword calling Danny Boy.
[last lines]
Do me a favor, will you? Next time you have one of these things, keep it an all-British operation.
I'll try, Lieutenant.

Look, Major, either you start playing it straight or you can deal me out of this mess. Now we both know that radio operator wasn't killed in any drop. Now with MacPherson dead, there's only five of us left. So either you let me know what's going on or there's only gonna be four.
Nobody leaves here until I come back. Jock, save me some coffee.
It'll be cold by then.
They say that's an advantage. You can't taste cold coffee.
[repeated line]

[to Smith]
We've got company.
I nearly froze to death in that damn plane. Why couldn't you have supplied some hot water bottles or an electrically heated suit? I thought you loved me.
Can't help what you think.
[after Schaffer kills a German with a knife]
That was quick.
Fear lent him wings, as the saying goes.

[to Smith, seeing him with Mary]
You seem to have a lot of women stashed around this country, Major.

[referring to Smith]
Some people have a sixth sense. He has a sixth, a seventh and an eighth.

[referring to Colonel Turner]
They say he knew Hitler quite well.
Yeah, I THOUGHT he looked a little nuts.
You're late.
One day, I won't come at all.
Let me remind you, Major, I'm a colonel in the SS and not a lieutenant who you can frighten with your threats!
Your military rank and position are obvious to me, Colonel, and so are your attempts to discredit me with superiors in Berlin.
If there is any discredit, you bring it upon yourself. Good night.
Now, General Carnaby, perhaps you'll be good enough to give us your real name, rank and serial number.
[shoots the chair]

[long pause, then]
Cartwright Jones, Corporal, U.S. Army RA 123-025-3964.
Thank you.
This is preposterous!
[when Smith makes the discussion more confusing than it already was]
There's a stop and start button.
[for the cable car]
See if you can make the motor work.
You are going up to the castle tonight as, well, yes as a domestic.
How? Naked?
Not a bad idea, but it's a bit obvious.
[a large body of German troops led by field security chief Colonel Weissner storm into the guesthouse pub in a raid]

[addressing the crowd]
Attention! We are looking for four or five Alpinekorps deserters from Studguardt. To escape they killed two officers and a guardroom sergeant. They were last known to be heading this way.

[quitely to his men]
Clever. Very clever indeed.

[continuting to the crowd]
I want all the officers of Drafts 13, 14, and 15 to come forward at once!
[to his men]
Check their papers. Check them carefully.

[to his men]
Well gentlemen... any suggestions?
[Thomas, Christiansen, and Berkley are silent]

[to Schaffer]
Lieutenant?
Well, I think we'll stand a lot better chance of getting away outside then we will in here.
Agreed. Gentlemen... see you after the war.
Security? The word's become a bloody joke!

[In the Werfen gasthaus cafe]
And who might you be, my pretty Alpine rose?
Heidi. Stop, Major. I've got important work to do.
There's no more important work than entertaining the soldiers of the Fatherland. Shall I sing you a song?
I hear too much singing.

[to Mary Ellison disguised as "Maria Schenk"]
My dear cousin Maria, you came after all.
Better lock the door.

[Von Hapen surprised Smith and Schaffer]
Stay where you are! I advise everyone to be perfectly still. Drop your gun, Major. You too, Lieutenant. By the fireplace.
Thank God you're here, Major, we're just about...

[interrupts Kramer]
SIT DOWN, colonel! Everybody remain as he is, until I find out what exactly is going on in here.

[to Schaeffer]
In your own idiom, you're a 'punk'. And a pretty second rate punk at that.
You must be mad.
If I wasn't, what would I be doing in this job?
Strange... I seem to remember... that the cathedral was on the other side of the square.
